**Case Summary: Bennett Coleman & Co. Ltd. vs. Arg Outlier Media Pvt Ltd & Ors. (CS(COMM) 434/2017)**

**Background:**
The present case is a commercial suit filed by Bennett Coleman & Co. Ltd. (the plaintiff) against Arg Outlier Media Pvt Ltd & Ors. (the defendants) in the High Court of Delhi. The plaintiff has filed an application under Order XI Rule 5 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (CPC) to place additional documents on record.

**Legal Issues:**
The primary issue in this case is whether the plaintiff is entitled to file additional documents, which were not part of the original suit, to counter the arguments raised by the defendants in their written statement. The plaintiff argues that these documents are necessary to demonstrate the existence of the defendant company at the time of filing the suit and to show that the defendants have taken contrary stands on the nature of the trademarks/taglines in question.

**Arguments:**

* The plaintiff argues that the additional documents are necessary to meet the arguments raised by the defendants in their written statement and to demonstrate the existence of the defendant company.
* The plaintiff relies on Order XI Rule (1) (c)(ii) of the CPC, which allows for the filing of additional documents to prove a fact that is relevant to the case.
* The defendants argue that the documents are no longer relevant as the defendant company has already been deleted from the array of parties.
* The defendants also argue that there is no contradiction in their stands on the nature of the trademarks/taglines and that the documents sought to be filed were in the power, possession, control, and custody of the plaintiff at the time of filing the suit.

**Court Findings:**
The court has examined the additional documents sought to be placed on record by the plaintiff, which include examination reports of the Registry and responses thereto by the defendants. The court notes that these documents pertain to the defendants and are relevant to the case.

**Decision:**
The decision of the court is not explicitly stated in the provided pages. However, based on the arguments and the court's examination of the documents, it can be inferred that the court is likely to allow the plaintiff to file the additional documents, as they appear to be relevant to the case and are necessary to meet the arguments raised by the defendants.

**Relevant Precedents:**
The defendants have relied on two judgments: Sudhir Kumar v. Vinay Kumar (2021 SCC OnLine SC 734) and Nitin Gupta v. Taxmaco Infrastructure & Holding Ltd. (2019 SCC OnLine Del 8367). However, the court's consideration of these precedents is not explicitly stated in the provided pages.

Overall, the case highlights the importance of filing relevant documents in a timely manner and the court's discretion in allowing additional documents to be placed on record. The decision of the court will depend on the specific facts and circumstances of the case, as well as the applicable laws and precedents.

6. 
I have heard the counsel for the parties.  
7. 
A perusal of the additional documents sought to be placed on record 
by the plaintiff would show that the said documents are the examination 
reports of the Registry and the responses thereto by the defendants. All the 
aforesaid documents pertain to the defendants. Attention of the Court has 
been drawn by the counsel for the plaintiff to paragraph 18 of the written 
statement filed by the defendant no.2, where a specific stand has been taken 
by the defendants that the trademark/taglines, which are the subject matter 
of the present suit are descriptive in nature. The aforesaid contention has 
been rebutted by the plaintiff in its replication. In order to meet the aforesaid 
contention of the defendants, the plaintiff seeks to place on record the 
aforesaid documents to show that in their replies to the examination reports, 
the defendants have claimed the trademark to be distinctive. The aforesaid 
documents are covered within the ambit of sub-rule (1)(c)(ii) of Rule (1) of 
Order XI of the CPC in terms of which the plaintiff would be entitled to file 
the documents in response to a case set up by the defendants after filing of 
the plaint. Therefore, there is no merit in the submission of the defendants 
that the aforesaid documents were available in public domain and could 
have been filed along with the plaint. Even if the said documents were 
available in public domain at the time of filing of the suit, the need for filing 
the aforesaid documents arose only on account of the stand taken by the 
defendants in the written statement.

Insofar as the objection of the defendants that the documents in 
respect of the defendant no.1 are not relevant as the defendant no.1 has been 
deleted from the array of the parties, it is the contention of the plaintiff that 
despite the defendants claiming that the defendant no.1 was not in existence, 
certain replies were filed on behalf of the defendant no.1 before the Trade 
Mark Registry. Therefore, the aforesaid documents are relevant for 
determining whether an incorrect stand has been taken by the defendant or 
not.   
9. 
In Sudhir Kumar (supra), relied upon by the defendants, the Supreme 
Court was dealing with the provisions of Order XI Rule 1(4) read with Order 
XI Rule 1(5) of the CPC in respect of filing additional documents after filing 
of the plaint in case of urgent listings. It was further observed that the rigour 
of establishing reasonable cause for non-disclosure of the documents along 
with the plaint may not arise in cases where additional documents are 
discovered subsequent to filing of the plaint. The aforesaid judgment does 
not in any manner curtail the power of the Court to permit additional 
documents to be taken on record if a party gives sufficient cause for not 
filing the said documents along with the plaint.

framed in the suit and additional documents sought to be filed by the

11. 
The judgments in Hassad Food Company (supra), Mahesh 
Chaudhri  (supra) and Nitin Gupta (supra) were considered by me in 
Khurmi Associates (P) Ltd. v. Maharishi Dayanand Co-Operative Group 
Housing Society, 2022 SCC OnLine Del 1011. Relying upon the judgments

tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "Bennet Coleman & Co. Ltd vs. ARG Outlier Media Pvt. Ltd & Ors.pdf" (2023/DHC/001726), a legal proceeding (CS(COMM) 434/2017) took place in the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi. The plaintiff, Bennett Coleman & Co. Ltd, was represented by Mr. Hemant Singh and other advocates, while the defendants were ARG Outlier Media Pvt Ltd and others.

The court considered the plaintiff's application to place additional documents on record, which included examination reports of the Registry and responses from the defendants. The documents pertained to the defendants' claim that the trademark/taglines in question were descriptive in nature. The plaintiff sought to rebut this contention by showing that the defendants had previously claimed the trademark to be distinctive in their replies to the examination reports.

The court allowed the plaintiff to file the additional documents, citing sub-rule (1)(c)(ii) of Rule 1 of Order XI of the CPC, which permits the filing of documents in response to a case set up by the defendants after the plaint has been filed. The court rejected the defendants' argument that the documents were available in the public domain and could have been filed with the plaint, stating that the need to file them arose only after the defendants' written statement was filed.

The decision was made on March 6, 2023, and the court relied on judgments from the Supreme Court (Sudhir Kumar v. Vinay Kumar, 2021 SCC OnLine SC 734) and a coordinate bench of the Delhi High Court (Nitin Gupta v. Taxmaco Infrastructure & Holding Ltd., 2019 SCC OnLine Del 8367). (Source: Bennet Coleman & Co. Ltd vs. ARG Outlier Media Pvt. Ltd & Ors.pdf)

nodes.summary: According to page 5 of the PDF "18. Bennet Coleman & Co. Ltd vs. ARG Outlier Media Pvt. Ltd & Ors.pdf" (2023/DHC/001726), the court allowed the plaintiff to file additional documents. The court relied on previous judgments in Hassad Food Company, Mahesh Chaudhri, and Nitin Gupta, which permitted additional documents to be filed when issues were yet to be framed in the suit. The court found the facts in this case similar to Khurmi Associates (2022 SCC OnLine Del 1011) and allowed the additional documents to be taken on record, subject to a cost of Rs.20,000/- to the defendants. The decision was made on March 6, 2023, in CS(COMM) 434/2017, Bennet Coleman & Co. Ltd vs. ARG Outlier Media Pvt Ltd & Ors. The plaintiff's advocates included Mr. Hemant Singh and others.
nodes.content:
2023/DHC/001726 
 
CS(COMM) 434/2017                                                                                                      Page 5 of 6 
 
allowed to be taken on record on the ground that the issues were yet to be 
framed in the suit and additional documents sought to be filed by the 
plaintiff were relevant for the adjudication of the case.  
11. 
The judgments in Hassad Food Company (supra), Mahesh 
Chaudhri  (supra) and Nitin Gupta (supra) were considered by me in 
Khurmi Associates (P) Ltd. v. Maharishi Dayanand Co-Operative Group 
Housing Society, 2022 SCC OnLine Del 1011. Relying upon the judgments 
in Hassad Food Company (supra) and Mahesh Chaudhary (supra), the 
additional documents were permitted to be taken on record on the ground 
that issues were yet to be framed in the suit and the documents were in 
support of the pleadings of the plaintiff company.  
12. 
The facts in the present case are very similar to the facts in Khurmi 
Associates (supra). Issues are yet to be framed in the suit. It is an admitted 
position that the additional documents were filed on behalf of the plaintiff 
on the same date as the replication. A perusal of the pleadings in the suit 
would also show that the aforesaid documents sought to be filed are not 
contrary to the pleadings of the plaintiff in the suit. In my considered view, 
the aforesaid documents would be relevant for the adjudication of the 
present suit.  
13. 
Accordingly, the present application is allowed and the plaintiff is 
permitted to place the additional documents on record, subject to payment of 
costs of Rs.20,000/- to the defendants. 
CS(COMM) 434/2017
